issues.description: The problem statement and the provided template expect a no-argument Rideable.messageOnRide() that returns a String (UML and example usage show messageOnRide():String and Main calls r.messageOnRide()). However, the solution repository defines Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) and the implementing classes (Pig, Seal) override messageOnRide with an int parameter and include the speed in the returned string. This parameter mismatch between specification/template and solution will confuse students (they will implement a no-arg method) and prevents consistent compilation/behavior across artifacts.
issues.suggested_fix: Choose one consistent signature for messageOnRide across all artifacts. To match the problem statement and template, change the solution to declare Rideable.messageOnRide() with no parameters (String messageOnRide()), and update Pig and Seal to override messageOnRide() with no parameters, returning the exact format required by the spec (e.g. "Riding on Pig Doodle" / "Riding on Seal Clarabelle"). Also ensure any example calls (Main) and tests use the no-arg form. Alternatively, if the intent was to include a speed parameter, update the problem statement, UML, template Main, and examples to require messageOnRide(int speed) and document the expected string format including the speed.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and instructions) and the template expect a Rideable interface method messageOnRide() with no parameters (returns String). The solution repository defines Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) (takes an int) and Pig/Seal implement the parameterized signature. This is a semantic/signature mismatch: students following the problem/template will implement a no-arg messageOnRide(), but the solution uses a different method signature and semantics (includes speed and modifies the returned string). This breaks the one-to-one mapping between the exercise requirements, the starter code's examples (Main.java calls messageOnRide() with no argument), and the reference implementation, creating confusion and likely compilation/test mismatches.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Rideable API across all artifacts. Either (A) change the solution to match the problem/template by removing the int parameter: declare Rideable.messageOnRide() : String and update Pig and Seal to implement messageOnRide() returning "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]" (no speed), or (B) if the intent is to include a speed parameter, update the problem statement, UML, and template Main examples to use messageOnRide(int speed) and document the speed semantics. Option A is recommended to preserve the current exercise text and template usage.
